p: An alternative way to block the activity of the SARS-CoV is to target the spike protein (S) of SARS-CoV S proteins or blocking the human ACE2 receptor. Yi et al. (2004) reported that tetra-O-galloyl Î²- d-glucose from Galla chinensis and luteolin from Veronica linariifolia exhibit strong binding affinity to spike (S) protein of SARS-CoV. Emodin (1,3,8-trihydroxy-6-methylanthraquinone), rhein (1,8-dihydroxy-3-carboxyl-910-anthraquinone), and chrysin (5,7-dihydroxyflavone) are produced in high levels in plants of genus Rheum and Polygonum; these compounds were responsible for blocking the binding of S protein in SARS-CoV to ACE2 ( Ho et al., 2007; Fig. 5). Emodin blocked the binding of S protein to ACE2 in a dose-dependent manner ( Ho et al., 2007).
